questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Boutonnière deformity The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Calcium oxalate The given urinary crystal is the bipyramidal or envelope-shaped crystals of calcium oxalate dihydrate. Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include higher urine calcium, urine oxalate, and lower urine citrate. Oxalate-rich foods like spinach, rhubarb, almonds, and potatoes should be avoided. Avoiding high-dose vitamin C supplements reduces endogenous oxalate production.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with the findings shown in the image below. He also complained of pain in the upper and lower limbs. On examination, his BP was 160/100 mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. Serology was negative for ANCA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Polyarteritis nodosa The most probable diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. The image shows the gangrene of the fingers. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA make polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) the most probable diagnosis. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of her hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. She has been treated with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine, but the disease is still progressing. Which of the following would be the next most appropriate step in further management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Perform IGRA test The clinical history and image are suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in the management of rheumatoid arthritis when the patient is not responding to methotrexate alone. Biologicals such as anti-TNF-alpha agents are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. But, before starting anti-TNF alpha agents, latent tuberculosis must be ruled out with an IGRA test or PPD. Additionally, viral hepatitis B and C, complete blood counts, and liver function tests should be done before initiating anti-TNF agents.

questions.text: A patient with chronic gout now presented to the emergency room after sustaining trauma to his left foot. Identify the abnormality in his X-ray given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Martel’s sign The given X-ray of a patient with chronic gout shows Martel’s sign. Martel’s sign also known as the G sign, or rat-bite erosion, refers to the punched-out lytic lesion and overhanging margin of the new bone along the edge of erosion seen in chronic tophaceous gout.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Centromeric The given picture shows discrete and large speckles in the resting cells, and the alignment of the speckles in the chromosome region in the dividing cells. This is suggestive of centromeric pattern of ANA staining. Centromeric pattern is seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dermatomyositis The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with muscle weakness, abnormal tingling sensation over the face, and pain and swelling over the knee joint for 3 months. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Investigations show hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalciuria with metabolic alkalosis. His x-ray knee is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gitelman’s syndrome The clinical scenario of a young male presenting with muscle weakness, paresthesia over the face, hypotension, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalciuria, metabolic alkalosis, and x-ray knee showing chondrocalcinosis as punctate density on the cartilage are suggestive of Gitelman’s syndrome. Gitelman’s syndrome is an autosomal recessive salt-losing renal tubulopathy. It occurs due to a mutation of Na+-CI co-transporter (NCCT) in the distal tubule.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with pain and swelling of his right knee for one week. It started progressing to the ankle joints and feet for the past 2 days. He gives a history of diarrhea and burning micturition 4 weeks ago. On examination, his soles showed the following lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Reactive arthritis The given scenario of acute arthritis following a recent infection and additive pattern (involvement of new joints within few days) and examination finding of keratoderma blennorrhagica (image) are suggestive of reactive arthritis. Keratoderma blennorrhagica is a mucocutaneous manifestation of reactive arthritis. It presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions or crusting on the palms and soles.

questions.text: A patient who has been diagnosed with hepatitis C infection now presents to the hospital with reddish-colored urine. Urine analysis was performed, and it shows proteinuria and the presence of red blood cells and leucocytes in the urine. A renal biopsy was performed, and the obtained sample was stained with periodic acid-Schiff (image A) and methenamine silver (image B). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis This patient, who is diagnosed with hepatitis C, presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and pyuria and histological examination shows the thickening and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane, giving rise to the tram-track appearance. The most likely diagnosis in this case is membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is immune-mediated glomerulonephritis characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with mesangio-proliferative changes.

questions.text: A girl was brought by her parents with an itchy rash as shown in the image below. She also complains of difficulty in climbing stairs. A muscle biopsy reveals peri-fascicular atrophy. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive Myxovirus resistance protein A. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dermatomyositis The given image of Gottron’s papules along with the history suggestive of proximal muscle weakness and the investigation findings are suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy. It is characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the ER with severe pain and swelling as shown in the image below. He told that he had consumed 2 bottles of beer a few hours before. Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Allopurinol The given scenario is suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Allopurinol is used in the management of chronic gout. Urate-lowering drugs such as allopurinol, probenecid, and lesinurad are not initiated during acute attacks.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man has several months of dysphagia to solid foods and a “sticky” feeling in his throat when eating. He experiences transient chest pain with hot beverages that lasts a few seconds. His medical history is unremarkable. Esophageal manometry shows periodic, high-amplitude, nonperistaltic waves. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Diffuse esophageal spasm The patient presents with chest pain and dysphagia without heartburn. Manometry shows periodic, high-amplitude, nonperistaltic waves, indicating diffuse esophageal spasm. This condition involves uncoordinated contractions that hinder effective food propulsion. The cause is often unknown, but it may be linked to uncontrolled GERD, with cold and hot beverages triggering

questions.text: What clinical examination is being performed in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fluid thrill Fluid thrill, also known as fluid wave, is another technique used to detect ascites. The patient or an assistant places their hand firmly on the midline of the abdomen, and the examiner taps one side of the abdomen sharply with their hand or fingers. If ascitic fluid is present, a palpable wave of fluid can be felt across the abdomen.

questions.text: Type of polyps in syndrome of a patient with shown Melanotic macules with STK11 gene mutation are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Peutz-Jegher's polyps is rare AD characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps scattered throughout GIT, along with mucosal and cutaneous melanotic pigmentation along lips, face, genitalia and palms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, recently discharged from the hospital, develops severe diarrhea and abdominal pain. Sigmoidoscopy reveals a granular friable mucosa. Which of the following is the most common cause of this syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cephalosporin therapy This diarrhea secondary to Clostridium difficile infection. Cephalosporins, because they are so widely used, are the most common cause of the disease.

questions.text: Depicted pictorial representation of murmur can be heard in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) VSD with aortic regurgitation VSD with aortic regurgitation produces pansystolic and early diastolic murmur, not continuous.

choices.text: Use of an automated external defibrillator

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with valvular heart disease has had a fever for the past two weeks and is now unconscious, as shown by the ECG. What treatment should be administered to this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The flat line on the ECG indicates asystole or cardiac arrest. In this case, the treatment for the patient is to restart the heart by administering 1 mg of IV adrenaline. A DC shock is contraindicated in the presence of a flat line ECG.

choices.text: Clockwise rotation of the electrical axis
High-voltage QRS complexes in V5 and V6
Prolonged PR interval in the limb leads

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with a 35-year history of hypertension and cardiomegaly on Chest X-ray is likely to show which of the following on his ECG?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) High-voltage QRS complexes in V5 and V6 Signs include left axis deviation, highvoltage QRS complexes in V5 and V6, deep S in V1 and V2, and prolonged QRS in the left precordial leads

questions.text: What valvular lesion is most commonly associated with a young woman presenting with the shown features?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aortic Insufficiency The most common cause of isolated aortic insufficiency (AI) in patients undergoing aortic valve replacement (AVR) is aortic root disease, which accounts for over 50% of such cases in some studies. A common heart condition associated with Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS), especially the hypermobile type, is aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm due to weakened connective tissue affecting large arteries, including the aorta. Additionally, the "cardiac-valvular" type of EDS can cause significant valve dysfunction, particularly affecting the mitral and aortic valves.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with type 2 diabetes and neuropathy fell and hit her head. After 10 days, her headache worsened, she vomited, and developed right arm weakness. At the hospital, her GCS was 15/15, but extensor plantar reflexes were present. What is the best management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Decompressive surgery In cases of subdural hemorrhage, management is based on bleed volume, location, and GCS. Decompressive surgery is needed if the GCS is low, the bleed exceeds 30 cc, or is infratentorial, to relieve intracranial pressure and prevent neurological decline.

questions.text: Which mineral is responsible for parkinsonism-like symptoms in a 16-year-old with progressive worsening and specific MRI findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Copper Wilson's disease, also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the abnormal accumulation of copper in various tissues, particularly the liver and brain.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with no comorbidities reports forgetting the route home from a familiar grocery store and struggling to recall common item names. His MMSE score is 22. An MRI is requested. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MRI brain of Alzheimer's disease will show blunting of gyri and sulci which leads to pseudo-enlargement of the ventricles of the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of shown condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Diabetes mellitus: The causes of Subarachnoid hemorrhage are as follows: Trauma (Most common) Rupture of berry aneurysm Arteriovenous malformation Charcot Bouchard aneurysm Extension of intracerebral hemorrhage: Hypertensive crisis

questions.text: What is the most probable cause for a 22-year-old man who has a high-grade fever, a purpuric rash, and a CSF sample showing gram-negative diplococci?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neisseria meningitidis The above image is that of a purpuric rash which is seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitides. Neisseria meningitidis is a gram negative diplococci. Fulminant meningococcemia presents with a very high fever and hemorrhagic rash

questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for condition associated with shown radiological finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sulfadiazine + Pyrimethamine The patient with AIDS presents with cerebral toxoplasmosis, indicated by seizures, MRI showing basal ganglia lesions, and positive CSF IgM/IgG antibodies for Toxoplasma.

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the face of a clock and his drawing is shown below. What is the correct term to be used here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hemispatial neglect In the above image drawn by the patient, the clock is blank on one side. The hemispatial defect is the most accurate term used. It is the inability to report, respond, and orient to stimuli in one-half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has distal leg weakness, reduced muscle stretch reflexes, and muscle atrophy below the knee, with no tingling or numbness. Similar symptoms are noted in his elder brother. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT) is a hereditary neurological disorder affecting peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy, especially in distal limbs. Key features include reduced muscle stretch reflexes and absence of sensory symptoms like tingling or numbness, consistent with the case's findings. The primary manifestation of CMT is motor dysfunction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with complaints of enlarged chest and milk secretion. Upon examination, spade-like hands, coarse facies, and macroglossia are noted. What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mixed Mammosomatotroph Adenoma The symptoms of spade-like hands, coarse facies, and macroglossia indicate acromegaly. The presence of galactorrhea in males, along with acromegaly features, suggests elevated growth hormone and prolactin levels. Mixed mammosomatotroph adenoma secretes both hormones, leading to galactorrhea and hypogonadism.

questions.text: The patient in question is a 25-year-old male who presented with symptoms of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also mentioned experiencing sweaty palms. The image provided below displays the clinical examination findings. Which diagnostic test is performed on this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Thyroid receptor antibody According to the vignette, the patient suffers from hyperthyroidism symptoms, including palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is Grave’s disease.

questions.text: What could be the possible reason for a diabetic patient to greet with a "namaste" gesture as shown upon entering your clinic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cheiroarthropathy Cheiroarthropathy is a condition often associated with diabetes mellitus, characterized by thickened, tight skin over the hands that limits joint mobility. This leads to difficulty fully extending the fingers, creating a hand posture resembling the "namaste" gesture. It is linked to poor glycemic control and the accumulation of advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) in the skin and soft tissues.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old male, what is the primary etiology typically associated with shown finding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pituitary Microadenoma Pituitary microadenoma is the most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male. Cushing's disease, a form of hypercortisolism, is caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. While other conditions can lead to Cushing's syndrome, "Cushing's disease" specifically refers to this ACTH-secreting tumor, which stimulates excessive cortisol production from the adrenal glands.

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the sign shown below and mark the option with the appropriate choice of treatment in its associated dyselectrolytemia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Calcium Gluconate The image illustrates the Trousseau sign, which is indicative of tetany resulting from hypocalcemia. A calcium level below 7 mg/dL can lead to these symptoms. The recommended treatment for this condition is intravenous 10% calcium gluconate.

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman was found to have a restrictive disease with reduced lung volumes on a pulmonary function test. A high-resolution CT of the thorax was done and is shown below. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Inspiratory coarse crackles The above HRCT shows a honeycomb appearance of lung parenchyma due to interstitial fibrosis in a restrictive lung disorder that is suggestive of interstitial lung disease (ILD). Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease. Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal end-inspiratory fine crackles also called velcro crackles or rales.

questions.text: A patient comes to the sleep clinic and the following pattern is seen on polysomnography. What type of breathing pattern is it?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cheyne-Stokes respiration The breathing pattern shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes respiration. It is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing, followed by a gradual decrease that results in a temporary stop in breathing called apnea.

questions.text: A 40-year-old asthma patient complains of a cough with brownish expectoration. He is not responding to his usual therapy for asthma. He has elevated circulating levels of IgE and prominent peripheral eosinophilia. His chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis A history of asthma in this patient, along with cough with brownish expectoration and elevated circulating IgE and eosinophilia, and a chest radiograph showing the characteristic finger-in-glove sign, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).

questions.text: An HIV-positive female patient presents with fever and dry cough for 4 weeks. Her chest X-ray is given below and her CD4+ T cell count is 150 cells/microliter. A lung biopsy was done that showed foamy alveolar infiltrates and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates on H & E staining. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Co-trimoxazole In the given clinical scenario, chest x-ray findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrate and H & E staining findings are suggestive of pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii and co-trimoxazole is the drug of choice for treatment as well as prophylaxis. Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungus that is found in patients having a CD4+ T cell count <200/?L.

choices.text: Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.text: A patient presents with the following laboratory values: Which of the following best describes the patient’s acid-base status?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Anion gap metabolic acidosis plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis Option C: 1. Anion Gap (AG): AG = Na (CI+ HCO?) = 138-(112+ 8) = 18 (Normal ~12 Elevated AG indicates anion gap metabolic acidosis.) 2. Delta Gap (AAG): AAG = AG_actual – AG_normal = 18 -12=6 3. Expected Drop in HCO, if Only AG Acidosis: ~6 mEq/L 4. Actual Drop in HCO?: 24-816 mEq/L 5. Delta-Delta Ratio: (AAG / AHCO?) = 6/16 = 0.38 (<1), indicating a second metabolic acidosis (normal anion gap) in addition to the high anion gap acidosis.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation

questions.text: A patient has the following laboratory findings: Which of the following is the most likely acid-base status?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Metabolic acidosis plus primary respiratory alkalosis The pH of 7.36 indicates compensated acidemia. The low bicarbonate (13 mEq/L) suggests primary metabolic acidosis, while the low PCO? (24 mmHg) indicates a coexisting respiratory alkalosis beyond expected compensation. Using Winter’s formula, the expected PCO? for pure metabolic acidosis is calculated as: Expected PCO? = (1.5 × HCO3-) +8±2 Expected PCO? = (1.5×13) +8+2=27.5 ± 2 (range: 25.5-29.5) The measured PCO? of 24 mmHg is lower than expected, indicating a primary respiratory alkalosis in addition to the metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Chest X-ray of an emphysematous patient is as shown. What is the best investigation to measure his lung volume?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Body plethysmography Body plethysmography is the best investigation to measure lung volume in an emphysematous patient with bullous lesions as seen on the X-ray.
